text:
I have some landing pages the have "no index" tag in them. Will Google still register that there's activity on those pages and thus register that we have traffic and give us the _seo boost_ associated?

*TL;DR* - *Does "no index" stop your page from getting an seo boost?*

elements.text: I have some landing pages the have "no index" tag in them. Will Google still register that there's activity on those pages and thus register that we have traffic and give us the
seo boost
associated?
TL;DR
Does "no index" stop your page from getting an seo boost?

text: if you want your page to get an SEO boost then why do you have the no index tag on it?

elements.text: if you want your page to get an SEO boost then why do you have the no index tag on it?

text: Technically only our customers should visit the page so we don't want it to be found through the SERps

elements.text: Technically only our customers should visit the page so we don't want it to be found through the SERps

text:
`No Index` says to Google, “Hey, you can crawl this page and follow the links, but DON’T tell anyone about it [in the serps]”

Will traffic to those no-indexed pages help boost the other pages on your site? _Maybe_. But that’s going to be a tiny ranking factor (site traffic) combined with a ‘don’t pay attention to this’ signal to Google.

On the balance:

• ‘No Index’ stops your page from getting an SEO boost
• Those ‘no indexed’ pages won’t boost the performance of other pages on your site

elements.text: No Index

Maybe

. But that’s going to be a tiny ranking factor (site traffic) combined with a ‘don’t pay attention to this’ signal to Google.

On the balance:
‘No Index’ stops your page from getting an SEO boost
Those ‘no indexed’ pages won’t boost the performance of other pages on your site

text: Hmm maybe if I added a canonical tag to it the "SEO juice could flow to a different page of my choosing?

elements.text: Hmm maybe if I added a canonical tag to it the "SEO juice could flow to a different page of my choosing?

text:
Good idea, but not good in practice.

<https://www.searchenginejournal.com/google-dont-mix-noindex-relcanonical/262607/>

> Google’s John Mueller advises site owners not to mix signals like noindex and rel=canonical.
> 
> The two signals are contradictory pieces of information, Mueller says, and Google will end up picking one over the other.
> 
> In general, Google will pick rel=canonical over noindex in cases where both signals are being used.

attachments.title: Google: Don’t Mix Noindex & Rel=Canonical
attachments.text: Google’s John Mueller advises site owners not to mix signals like noindex and rel=canonical.
attachments.fallback: Search Engine Journal: Google: Don’t Mix Noindex & Rel=Canonical

elements.text: Good idea, but not good in practice.

Google’s John Mueller advises site owners not to mix signals like noindex and rel=canonical.

The two signals are contradictory pieces of information, Mueller says, and Google will end up picking one over the other.

In general, Google will pick rel=canonical over noindex in cases where both signals are being used.

text:
That ‘SEO Juice’ phrase is mostly used/relevant in terms of _link juice_ flowing from incoming links to your site.

If you don’t have a lot of links pointing to these pages, I wouldn’t worry too much about getting that SEO juice flowing elsewhere. I do not think it’ll make a big difference.

If you want to boost the performance of other pages, then I’d recommend looking at internal linking and external linking on other pages on your site first (e.g., is your homepage linking in the body content to your target page for the boost?)

text:
Ah, so the flow would be:

1. Launch pages, set as no-index
2. Drive current customers to those pages (e.g., through email)
3. Google boosts overall performance of the _site_ based on that increase in traffic
?

If so, it _could_ work, but an additional hesitation on my part is:

1. When I’ve heard of traffic as a ranking signal in the short-term, it’s typically only been a boost for _the page getting more traffic_, not the site as a whole. And doesn’t last forever, just a few days/week. 
Which means if these are no-index pages _and_ meant only for customers _and_ you’re looking for an SEO boost, I don’t think it will result in the outcome you’re looking for.

text: Hoe would Google know about a page’s traffic, if the page is noindexed and thus won’t get organic traffic?

elements.text: Hoe would Google know about a page’s traffic, if the page is noindexed and thus won’t get organic traffic?

text:
That answer gets a little scary OR conspiracy fueled:

• If Google Analytics is on the domain, they can see all traffic (e.g., referral, email, organic, direct…)
• If people are accessing through Google Chrome, they can see the traffic
• If you’re running other Google scripts/tools (e.g., adwords script, GTM) — and depending on how tight your tinfoil hat is — they can see traffic from that as well
I know from first hand experience that bursts of non-organic traffic can trigger that ranking boost (e.g., you went viral on Twitter and got a TON of traffic? Google will think, ‘oh this is very relevant and timely now, I will boost that page in the SERPs’)

elements.text: That answer gets a little scary OR conspiracy fueled:

If people are accessing through Google Chrome, they can see the traffic
If you’re running other Google scripts/tools (e.g., adwords script, GTM) — and depending on how tight your tinfoil hat is — they can see traffic from that as well

I know from first hand experience that bursts of non-organic traffic can trigger that ranking boost (e.g., you went viral on Twitter and got a TON of traffic? Google will think, ‘oh this is very relevant and timely now, I will boost that page in the SERPs’)

text:
So many SEO questions from me today ugh :man-facepalming:

If I built a pillar page out of a bunch of blogs on my site to create a massive "guide" would I get *dinged for duplicate content?* The page would take sections of multipole blogs and piece them together kind of like a sparks note for each blog all on one page. Would that be considered duplicate content?

elements.text: So many SEO questions from me today ugh
If I built a pillar page out of a bunch of blogs on my site to create a massive "guide" would I get
dinged for duplicate content?
The page would take sections of multipole blogs and piece them together kind of like a sparks note for each blog all on one page. Would that be considered duplicate content?

text: I suspect that if it's verbatim text from one page to another that's got to get noticed. Why not just spend the time to rewrite a new blurb about each segment for the guide?

elements.text: I suspect that if it's verbatim text from one page to another that's got to get noticed. Why not just spend the time to rewrite a new blurb about each segment for the guide?

text:
You’re safe with your approach, Ryan.

Google has clarified that duplicate content is more of a caution that if you have the exact same content on multiple pages (e.g., 5 product pages with the exact same content) you’ll have trouble ranking. Which page is the most relevant? Hard to say, because the content is the same.

In this case, your approach reusing excerpts from blog posts is 100% fine. Google has said that this is an acceptable reuse of content, not a duplicate content risk.

elements.text:

In this case, your approach reusing excerpts from blog posts is 100% fine. Google has said that this is an acceptable reuse of content, not a duplicate content risk.
